title: Scarlett: coping with skewed content popularity in mapreduce clusters.
abstract: MapReduce clusters are increasingly being used to process large datasets. However, many MapReduce jobs exhibit skewed content popularity, where a small fraction of keys account for a large fraction of the data. This skew can cause significant performance degradation, as a few reducers become overloaded while others remain idle. We present Scarlett, a system that addresses this problem by dynamically adapting to skewed content popularity. Scarlett uses a combination of techniques including dynamic key redistribution, speculative execution, and adaptive partitioning to balance the load across reducers. Our evaluation shows that Scarlett can improve job completion time by up to 3x for jobs with highly skewed data.

title: DepSky: dependable and secure storage in a cloud-of-clouds.
abstract: Cloud storage services are becoming increasingly popular, but they raise concerns about dependability and security. We present DepSky, a system that provides dependable and secure storage by using multiple cloud storage providers (a cloud-of-clouds). DepSky replicates data across multiple clouds and uses cryptographic techniques to ensure confidentiality, integrity, and availability even when some clouds fail or are compromised. Our evaluation shows that DepSky can tolerate Byzantine failures and provides better availability and security than using a single cloud provider.

title: Kaleidoscope: cloud micro-elasticity via VM state coloring.
abstract: Cloud computing platforms need to provide fine-grained elasticity to efficiently handle varying workloads. However, traditional VM migration techniques are too coarse-grained and slow for micro-elasticity. We present Kaleidoscope, a system that enables micro-elasticity through VM state coloring, which allows VMs to be quickly cloned and scaled by sharing and managing VM state efficiently. Kaleidoscope uses a novel state coloring mechanism that tracks and manages VM state at a fine granularity, enabling rapid VM creation and migration. Our evaluation shows that Kaleidoscope can reduce VM startup time by up to 10x compared to traditional approaches.

title: Parallel symbolic execution for automated real-world software testing.
abstract: Symbolic execution is a powerful technique for automated software testing, but it suffers from scalability issues when applied to real-world software. We present a parallel symbolic execution system that can efficiently test large-scale applications by distributing the symbolic execution across multiple machines. Our system uses a novel approach to parallelize symbolic execution while maintaining soundness and completeness. We evaluate our system on several real-world applications and show that it can find bugs and achieve high code coverage significantly faster than sequential symbolic execution.

title: CloneCloud: elastic execution between mobile device and cloud.
abstract: Mobile devices have limited computational resources, but many applications could benefit from cloud computing. We present CloneCloud, a system that enables elastic execution between mobile devices and the cloud by automatically partitioning and migrating application code. CloneCloud uses static analysis and dynamic profiling to determine which parts of an application should run on the device and which should run in the cloud. Our evaluation shows that CloneCloud can improve application performance and reduce energy consumption on mobile devices.

title: Symbolic crosschecking of floating-point and SIMD code.
abstract: Floating-point and SIMD code is notoriously difficult to test and verify due to the complexity of floating-point arithmetic and the large number of possible execution paths. We present a symbolic crosschecking technique that can automatically verify the correctness of floating-point and SIMD implementations by comparing them against reference implementations. Our approach uses symbolic execution to explore the input space and detect discrepancies between implementations. We evaluate our technique on several real-world applications and show that it can find bugs and verify correctness properties.

title: Striking a new balance between program instrumentation and debugging time.
abstract: Program instrumentation is essential for debugging and performance analysis, but it often introduces significant overhead. We present a new approach that strikes a balance between instrumentation overhead and debugging effectiveness. Our system uses selective instrumentation and adaptive techniques to minimize overhead while maintaining the ability to diagnose problems. We evaluate our approach on several real-world applications and show that it can reduce instrumentation overhead by up to 80% while still providing effective debugging capabilities.

title: SRM-buffer: an OS buffer management technique to prevent last level cache from thrashing in multicores.
abstract: Last level cache (LLC) thrashing is a major performance problem in multicore systems. We present SRM-buffer, an OS-level buffer management technique that prevents LLC thrashing by intelligently managing buffer allocation and eviction. SRM-buffer uses a novel approach that considers both memory access patterns and cache behavior to optimize buffer placement. Our evaluation shows that SRM-buffer can reduce LLC misses by up to 40% and improve overall system performance by up to 25%.

title: Increasing performance in byzantine fault-tolerant systems with on-demand replica consistency.
abstract: Byzantine fault-tolerant systems typically maintain strong consistency among replicas, which can limit performance. We present an approach that uses on-demand replica consistency to improve performance while maintaining fault tolerance. Our system allows replicas to operate with relaxed consistency during normal operation and enforces strong consistency only when needed. We evaluate our approach and show that it can improve throughput by up to 3x compared to traditional Byzantine fault-tolerant systems.

title: Finding complex concurrency bugs in large multi-threaded applications.
abstract: Finding concurrency bugs in large multi-threaded applications is challenging due to the large number of possible interleavings. We present a new approach that can efficiently find complex concurrency bugs by using a combination of static analysis and dynamic testing. Our system uses novel techniques to explore the space of possible interleavings and identify problematic execution patterns. We evaluate our approach on several large applications and show that it can find bugs that are difficult to detect with existing tools.

title: Efficient middleware for byzantine fault tolerant database replication.
abstract: Byzantine fault-tolerant database replication is essential for building reliable distributed systems, but existing solutions often have high overhead. We present an efficient middleware that provides Byzantine fault-tolerant database replication with low overhead. Our middleware uses novel techniques to optimize replication protocols and reduce communication costs. We evaluate our middleware and show that it can achieve high throughput and low latency while maintaining strong consistency guarantees.

title: Keypad: an auditing file system for theft-prone devices.
abstract: Mobile devices are frequently lost or stolen, making data security a critical concern. We present Keypad, an auditing file system designed for theft-prone devices. Keypad provides comprehensive audit logging of file system operations while maintaining good performance. Our system uses novel techniques to efficiently log file access patterns and detect suspicious activities. We evaluate Keypad and show that it can provide effective auditing capabilities with minimal performance overhead.

title: Scheduling large jobs by abstraction refinement.
abstract: Scheduling large jobs in distributed systems is challenging due to the complexity of resource allocation and job dependencies. We present an approach that uses abstraction refinement to efficiently schedule large jobs. Our method starts with a coarse abstraction of the scheduling problem and iteratively refines it to find optimal or near-optimal schedules. We evaluate our approach on several large-scale workloads and show that it can improve job completion time and resource utilization compared to traditional scheduling algorithms.

title: Cycles, cells and platters: an empirical analysisof hardware failures on a million consumer PCs.
abstract: Understanding hardware failure patterns is crucial for building reliable systems, but large-scale empirical studies of hardware failures are rare. We present an empirical analysis of hardware failures on over a million consumer PCs, examining failures in CPUs (cycles), memory (cells), and storage (platters). Our study reveals interesting patterns in failure rates, failure modes, and correlations between different types of failures. We analyze the data to understand the root causes of failures and provide insights for system designers.

title: Fine-grained power modeling for smartphones using system call tracing.
abstract: Accurate power modeling is essential for understanding and optimizing energy consumption in smartphones, but existing models often lack fine-grained accuracy. We present a fine-grained power modeling approach that uses system call tracing to accurately model power consumption at the application level. Our model captures the relationship between system calls and power consumption, enabling accurate power attribution to individual applications and system components. We evaluate our model on several smartphones and show that it can achieve high accuracy in predicting power consumption.

title: Energy management in mobile devices with the cinder operating system.
abstract: Energy management is critical for mobile devices, but existing operating systems provide limited control over energy consumption. We present Cinder, an operating system designed specifically for energy management in mobile devices. Cinder provides fine-grained control over energy allocation and consumption, allowing applications to explicitly manage their energy budgets. We evaluate Cinder on several mobile devices and show that it can significantly improve battery life while maintaining application functionality.

title: Database engines on multicores, why parallelize when you can distribute?
abstract: Multicore processors have become ubiquitous, but database engines often struggle to fully utilize them. Traditional approaches focus on parallelizing database operations, but we argue that distribution can be more effective. We present a distributed approach to database engine design that leverages multicore architectures by treating cores as independent nodes in a distributed system. Our evaluation shows that this approach can achieve better scalability and performance than traditional parallelization techniques.

title: A case for scaling applications to many-core with OS clustering.
abstract: Many-core processors are becoming increasingly common, but scaling applications to effectively utilize many cores remains challenging. We present OS clustering, an approach that groups cores into clusters and runs separate operating system instances on each cluster. This approach allows applications to scale to many-core systems by treating each cluster as an independent node. We evaluate OS clustering and show that it can improve scalability and performance for many-core applications.

title: Is co-scheduling too expensive for SMP VMs?
abstract: Co-scheduling is a technique used in virtualized environments to improve performance by scheduling related virtual CPUs together. However, co-scheduling can be expensive, especially for SMP (Symmetric Multiprocessing) VMs. We investigate the cost of co-scheduling for SMP VMs and propose optimizations to reduce this cost. Our evaluation shows that while co-scheduling can improve performance, the overhead can be significant, and we provide guidelines for when co-scheduling is beneficial.

title: Refuse to crash with Re-FUSE.
abstract: FUSE (Filesystem in Userspace) is a popular framework for implementing file systems in user space, but FUSE-based file systems are vulnerable to crashes that can lead to data loss or corruption. We present Re-FUSE, a reliable version of FUSE that provides crash recovery capabilities. Re-FUSE uses logging and checkpointing techniques to ensure that file system operations can be recovered after crashes. We evaluate Re-FUSE and show that it can provide strong reliability guarantees with acceptable performance overhead.

title: Feature consistency in compile-time-configurable system software: facing the linux 10, 000 feature problem.
abstract: Linux kernel has grown to include over 10,000 configurable features, making it challenging to ensure feature consistency and correctness. We present an approach for analyzing and maintaining feature consistency in compile-time-configurable system software. Our approach uses static analysis to detect inconsistencies and conflicts between features. We apply our approach to the Linux kernel and identify numerous inconsistencies and potential bugs. We provide tools and techniques to help developers maintain feature consistency in large configurable systems.

title: Sierra: practical power-proportionality for data center storage.
abstract: Data center storage systems consume significant energy, but they often operate at low utilization, wasting energy. Power-proportional storage systems can reduce energy consumption by scaling power usage with workload. We present Sierra, a practical power-proportional storage system that achieves power-proportionality through intelligent power management and workload-aware resource allocation. Our evaluation shows that Sierra can reduce energy consumption by up to 60% while maintaining performance.

title: Operating system support for application-specific speculation.
abstract: Speculation can improve application performance by optimistically executing operations that may not be needed, but existing speculation mechanisms are limited. We present operating system support for application-specific speculation, allowing applications to define their own speculation strategies. Our system provides primitives for speculative execution, rollback, and conflict detection. We evaluate our approach and show that it can improve application performance while maintaining correctness.

title: ZZ and the art of practical BFT execution.
abstract: Byzantine fault-tolerant (BFT) systems provide strong guarantees but are often considered too expensive for practical use. We present ZZ, a practical BFT execution system that achieves high performance through optimizations and careful design. ZZ uses novel techniques to reduce the overhead of BFT protocols while maintaining strong fault tolerance guarantees. We evaluate ZZ and show that it can achieve performance comparable to non-fault-tolerant systems while providing Byzantine fault tolerance.

title: Fast black-box testing of system recovery code.
abstract: System recovery code is critical for system reliability, but testing recovery code is challenging because recovery scenarios are difficult to trigger. We present a fast black-box testing approach for system recovery code that uses fault injection to trigger recovery scenarios. Our approach can efficiently test recovery code without requiring source code access or system modifications. We evaluate our approach on several systems and show that it can find bugs in recovery code.

title: Jettison: efficient idle desktop consolidation with partial VM migration.
abstract: Desktop consolidation can reduce energy consumption by consolidating idle desktops onto fewer physical machines, but traditional VM migration is too slow and disruptive. We present Jettison, a system that uses partial VM migration to efficiently consolidate idle desktops. Jettison migrates only the essential parts of VMs, reducing migration time and overhead. Our evaluation shows that Jettison can consolidate desktops efficiently while maintaining user experience.

title: Improving interrupt response time in a verifiable protected microkernel.
abstract: Verifiable protected microkernels provide strong security guarantees through formal verification, but they often have poor interrupt response times due to the overhead of protection mechanisms. We present techniques to improve interrupt response time in verifiable protected microkernels while maintaining verification properties. Our approach uses optimized interrupt handling paths and careful design to reduce latency. We evaluate our approach and show that it can achieve interrupt response times comparable to unverified systems.

title: Scalable testing of file system checkers.
abstract: File system checkers (like fsck) are critical for maintaining file system integrity, but testing them is challenging due to the large number of possible file system states. We present a scalable testing approach for file system checkers that can efficiently generate and test corrupted file system states. Our approach uses symbolic execution and model checking to systematically explore file system states. We evaluate our approach and show that it can find bugs in file system checkers.

title: Energy efficiency for large-scale MapReduce workloads with significant interactive analysis.
abstract: Large-scale MapReduce workloads often include significant interactive analysis components, which have different energy characteristics than batch jobs. We present techniques to improve energy efficiency for MapReduce workloads with interactive analysis. Our approach uses workload-aware resource allocation and power management to reduce energy consumption while maintaining performance. We evaluate our approach on production workloads and show that it can reduce energy consumption by up to 40%.

title: Kineograph: taking the pulse of a fast-changing and connected world.

authors.name: Enhong Chen
affiliations: University of Science and Technology of China

abstract: Real-time graph processing is essential for understanding fast-changing and connected worlds, such as social networks. We present Kineograph, a distributed system for processing large-scale graphs in real-time. Kineograph uses novel techniques to handle graph updates efficiently while maintaining consistency. We evaluate Kineograph on several real-world workloads and show that it can process graph updates with low latency and high throughput.

title: LazyBase: trading freshness for performance in a scalable database.
abstract: Many applications can tolerate slightly stale data in exchange for better performance. We present LazyBase, a scalable database that trades data freshness for performance. LazyBase uses lazy evaluation and caching to reduce database load and improve response times. Applications can specify freshness requirements, and LazyBase optimizes performance while meeting these requirements. We evaluate LazyBase and show that it can significantly improve performance for read-heavy workloads.

title: BWS: balanced work stealing for time-sharing multicores.
abstract: Work stealing is an effective load balancing technique for parallel programs, but existing work stealing algorithms can cause cache contention and poor performance on time-sharing multicores. We present BWS (Balanced Work Stealing), a work stealing algorithm designed for time-sharing multicores. BWS uses cache-aware scheduling and balanced stealing to reduce contention and improve performance. We evaluate BWS and show that it can improve performance by up to 30% compared to traditional work stealing.

title: STM in the small: trading generality for performance in software transactional memory.
abstract: Software Transactional Memory (STM) provides a simple programming model for concurrent programs, but general-purpose STM implementations often have high overhead. We present a specialized STM implementation that trades generality for performance by targeting specific use cases. Our STM uses domain-specific optimizations to achieve better performance than general-purpose STMs. We evaluate our approach and show that it can improve performance by up to 2x for common workloads.

title: Jockey: guaranteed job latency in data parallel clusters.
abstract: Data parallel clusters need to provide latency guarantees for interactive jobs while maintaining high throughput for batch jobs. We present Jockey, a system that provides guaranteed job latency in data parallel clusters. Jockey uses predictive scheduling and resource allocation to ensure that jobs meet their latency requirements. We evaluate Jockey on production workloads and show that it can provide latency guarantees while maintaining high cluster utilization.

title: GreenHadoop: leveraging green energy in data-processing frameworks.
abstract: Data centers consume significant energy, but they can leverage green energy sources to reduce their carbon footprint. We present GreenHadoop, a system that leverages green energy in data-processing frameworks. GreenHadoop schedules jobs to maximize the use of available green energy while maintaining performance. We evaluate GreenHadoop and show that it can significantly increase green energy usage while maintaining job performance.

title: TM2C: a software transactional memory for many-cores.
abstract: Many-core processors require efficient concurrency control mechanisms. We present TM2C, a software transactional memory system designed for many-core architectures. TM2C uses novel techniques to scale to large numbers of cores while maintaining good performance. Our evaluation shows that TM2C can achieve high throughput and low latency on many-core systems, outperforming existing STM implementations.

title: CheapBFT: resource-efficient byzantine fault tolerance.
abstract: Byzantine fault-tolerant (BFT) systems provide strong guarantees but are often considered too resource-intensive for practical use. We present CheapBFT, a resource-efficient BFT system that reduces the resource requirements of BFT protocols. CheapBFT uses novel techniques to minimize replication overhead and communication costs while maintaining strong fault tolerance guarantees. We evaluate CheapBFT and show that it can achieve BFT with significantly lower resource requirements than existing systems.

title: Improving server applications with system transactions.
abstract: Server applications often need to perform complex operations atomically, but existing mechanisms are limited. We present system transactions, a mechanism that allows server applications to perform system-level operations atomically. System transactions provide atomicity guarantees for operations that span multiple system components. We evaluate system transactions and show that they can improve application reliability and simplify error handling.

title: Cache craftiness for fast multicore key-value storage.
abstract: Key-value storage systems need to efficiently utilize multicore processors, but cache contention can limit performance. We present cache craftiness techniques for fast multicore key-value storage. Our approach uses cache-aware data structures and algorithms to minimize cache misses and contention. We evaluate our approach and show that it can improve throughput by up to 2x compared to traditional key-value stores.

title: Delusional boot: securing hypervisors without massive re-engineering.
abstract: Hypervisor security is critical for cloud computing, but securing hypervisors often requires massive re-engineering. We present Delusional Boot, a technique for securing hypervisors without massive re-engineering. Delusional Boot uses hardware-based isolation and secure boot mechanisms to protect hypervisors from attacks. We evaluate Delusional Boot and show that it can provide strong security guarantees with minimal changes to existing hypervisors.

title: Where is the energy spent inside my app?: fine grained energy accounting on smartphones with Eprof.
abstract: Understanding where energy is spent in smartphone applications is crucial for optimizing battery life, but existing tools provide limited visibility. We present Eprof, a fine-grained energy accounting tool for smartphones. Eprof uses system call tracing and power modeling to attribute energy consumption to individual application components. We evaluate Eprof and show that it can accurately identify energy hotspots in applications.

title: Improving network connection locality on multicore systems.
abstract: Network connection locality is important for performance on multicore systems, but existing systems often fail to maintain locality. We present techniques to improve network connection locality on multicore systems. Our approach uses core-aware connection management and scheduling to keep connections on the same core. We evaluate our approach and show that it can improve network performance by up to 40%.

title: Frugal storage for cloud file systems.
abstract: Cloud file systems need to provide cost-effective storage while maintaining performance and reliability. We present frugal storage techniques for cloud file systems that reduce storage costs through intelligent data placement and compression. Our approach uses workload-aware optimization to minimize storage costs while maintaining performance. We evaluate our approach and show that it can reduce storage costs by up to 50%.

title: MadLINQ: large-scale distributed matrix computation for the cloud.
abstract: Large-scale matrix computation is essential for many cloud applications, but existing systems are complex and inefficient. We present MadLINQ, a distributed matrix computation system for the cloud. MadLINQ provides a LINQ-like programming interface for matrix operations and automatically parallelizes computations across cloud resources. We evaluate MadLINQ and show that it can efficiently handle large-scale matrix computations.

title: FlashTier: a lightweight, consistent and durable storage cache.
abstract: Storage caches can improve performance, but they often sacrifice consistency and durability for speed. We present FlashTier, a lightweight storage cache that provides consistency and durability guarantees. FlashTier uses flash memory as a cache tier and provides strong consistency guarantees through careful design. We evaluate FlashTier and show that it can improve performance while maintaining consistency and durability.

title: Practical TDMA for datacenter ethernet.
abstract: Datacenter networks need predictable performance, but Ethernet's best-effort service model makes this challenging. We present practical TDMA (Time Division Multiple Access) for datacenter Ethernet. Our approach uses time-slot scheduling to provide predictable network performance. We evaluate our approach and show that it can provide predictable latency and bandwidth guarantees while maintaining compatibility with existing Ethernet infrastructure.

title: Canal: scaling social network-based Sybil tolerance schemes.
abstract: Social network-based Sybil tolerance schemes can defend against Sybil attacks, but they often don't scale to large networks. We present Canal, a scalable Sybil tolerance scheme that uses social network structure to identify and isolate Sybil nodes. Canal uses efficient algorithms to scale to large networks while maintaining strong security guarantees. We evaluate Canal and show that it can effectively defend against Sybil attacks in large-scale social networks.

title: Isolating commodity hosted hypervisors with HyperLock.
abstract: Commodity hosted hypervisors are vulnerable to attacks that can compromise the entire system. We present HyperLock, a system for isolating commodity hosted hypervisors. HyperLock uses hardware-based isolation mechanisms to protect hypervisors from attacks. We evaluate HyperLock and show that it can provide strong isolation guarantees while maintaining performance.

title: The Xen-Blanket: virtualize once, run everywhere.
abstract: Virtual machines need to run on different hypervisors, but existing approaches require re-implementation or emulation. We present Xen-Blanket, a virtualization layer that allows VMs to run on any hypervisor. Xen-Blanket provides a uniform interface that abstracts away hypervisor differences. We evaluate Xen-Blanket and show that it can enable VM portability across different cloud platforms.

title: Delta-FTL: improving SSD lifetime via exploiting content locality.
abstract: SSD lifetime is limited by write wear, but existing FTL (Flash Translation Layer) designs don't exploit content locality. We present Delta-FTL, an FTL that exploits content locality to reduce writes and improve SSD lifetime. Delta-FTL uses delta encoding to store only changes, reducing write traffic. We evaluate Delta-FTL and show that it can significantly extend SSD lifetime.

title: A critique of snapshot isolation.
abstract: Snapshot isolation is widely used in databases, but it has subtle correctness issues. We present a critique of snapshot isolation, identifying its limitations and potential problems. We analyze the semantics of snapshot isolation and show that it can lead to anomalies in certain scenarios. We provide insights for database designers and users about when snapshot isolation is appropriate.

title: Eighth Eurosys Conference 2013, EuroSys '13, Prague, Czech Republic, April 14-17, 2013
abstract: Eighth EuroSys Conference 2013, held in Prague, Czech Republic, April 14-17, 2013. EuroSys is a premier conference for systems research in Europe.

title: BlinkDB: queries with bounded errors and bounded response times on very large data.
abstract: Querying very large datasets interactively is challenging due to long response times. We present BlinkDB, a system that provides queries with bounded errors and bounded response times on very large data. BlinkDB uses adaptive sampling to answer queries quickly while maintaining error bounds. We evaluate BlinkDB and show that it can answer queries in seconds on petabyte-scale datasets.

title: ChainReaction: a causal+ consistent datastore based on chain replication.
abstract: Causal consistency provides a good balance between consistency and performance, but existing implementations are complex. We present ChainReaction, a causal+ consistent datastore based on chain replication. ChainReaction uses chain replication to provide causal+ consistency with simple implementation. We evaluate ChainReaction and show that it can provide strong consistency guarantees with good performance.

title: A compiler-level intermediate representation based binary analysis and rewriting system.
abstract: Binary analysis and rewriting is challenging because binaries lack high-level semantic information. We present a compiler-level intermediate representation based binary analysis and rewriting system. Our system recovers compiler IR from binaries and uses it for analysis and rewriting. We evaluate our system and show that it can perform complex analyses and transformations on binaries.

title: Composing OS extensions safely and efficiently with Bascule.
abstract: OS extensions need to be composed safely and efficiently, but existing approaches are limited. We present Bascule, a system for composing OS extensions safely and efficiently. Bascule uses type-safe interfaces and isolation mechanisms to enable safe composition. We evaluate Bascule and show that it can compose extensions efficiently while maintaining safety guarantees.

title: hClock: hierarchical QoS for packet scheduling in a hypervisor.
abstract: Hypervisors need to provide QoS guarantees for network I/O, but existing scheduling algorithms don't support hierarchical QoS. We present hClock, a hierarchical QoS packet scheduling algorithm for hypervisors. hClock uses hierarchical token buckets to provide QoS guarantees at multiple levels. We evaluate hClock and show that it can provide fine-grained QoS control.

title: RadixVM: scalable address spaces for multithreaded applications.
abstract: Multithreaded applications need scalable address spaces, but existing VM designs don't scale well. We present RadixVM, a scalable address space design for multithreaded applications. RadixVM uses radix trees and fine-grained locking to enable scalable address space operations. We evaluate RadixVM and show that it can scale to thousands of threads.

title: MeT: workload aware elasticity for NoSQL.
abstract: NoSQL systems need to scale elastically with workload changes, but existing elasticity mechanisms are workload-agnostic. We present MeT, a workload-aware elasticity system for NoSQL. MeT uses workload analysis to make intelligent scaling decisions. We evaluate MeT and show that it can improve resource utilization and reduce costs.

title: Choosy: max-min fair sharing for datacenter jobs with constraints.
abstract: Datacenter schedulers need to provide fair resource sharing while respecting job constraints, but existing fair sharing algorithms don't handle constraints well. We present Choosy, a max-min fair sharing scheduler for datacenter jobs with constraints. Choosy uses constraint-aware algorithms to provide fair sharing. We evaluate Choosy and show that it can provide fair resource allocation while respecting constraints.

title: RapiLog: reducing system complexity through verification.
abstract: System complexity makes verification challenging, but verification can help reduce complexity. We present RapiLog, a verification approach that reduces system complexity through logging. RapiLog uses verified logging to simplify system design and enable formal verification. We evaluate RapiLog and show that it can reduce system complexity while maintaining performance.

title: Adaptive parallelism for web search.
abstract: Web search systems need to adapt parallelism to query characteristics and system load, but existing systems use fixed parallelism. We present an adaptive parallelism approach for web search that dynamically adjusts parallelism based on query characteristics and system conditions. Our approach uses machine learning to predict optimal parallelism. We evaluate our approach and show that it can improve search latency and throughput.

title: Hypnos: understanding and treating sleep conflicts in smartphones.
abstract: Sleep conflicts prevent smartphones from entering sleep mode, wasting battery life. We present Hypnos, a system for understanding and treating sleep conflicts in smartphones. Hypnos identifies applications that prevent sleep and provides mechanisms to resolve conflicts. We evaluate Hypnos and show that it can significantly improve battery life by resolving sleep conflicts.

title: Optimus: a dynamic rewriting framework for data-parallel execution plans.
abstract: Data-parallel execution plans need to adapt to runtime conditions, but existing systems use static plans. We present Optimus, a dynamic rewriting framework for data-parallel execution plans. Optimus monitors execution and dynamically rewrites plans to improve performance. We evaluate Optimus and show that it can improve job completion time by adapting to runtime conditions.

title: Mizan: a system for dynamic load balancing in large-scale graph processing.
abstract: Large-scale graph processing suffers from load imbalance, which limits performance. We present Mizan, a system for dynamic load balancing in large-scale graph processing. Mizan uses vertex migration and dynamic repartitioning to balance load during execution. We evaluate Mizan and show that it can improve performance by up to 3x compared to static partitioning.

title: MDCC: multi-data center consistency.
abstract: Multi-data center deployments need consistency guarantees across data centers, but existing systems have high latency. We present MDCC, a multi-data center consistency protocol that provides strong consistency with low latency. MDCC uses optimistic concurrency control and fast commit protocols. We evaluate MDCC and show that it can provide strong consistency with acceptable latency.

title: Conversion: multi-version concurrency control for main memory segments.
abstract: Main memory databases need efficient concurrency control, but existing MVCC implementations have high overhead. We present Conversion, a multi-version concurrency control system for main memory segments. Conversion uses segment-level versioning to reduce overhead. We evaluate Conversion and show that it can provide high concurrency with low overhead.

title: Prefetching mobile ads: can advertising systems afford it?
abstract: Prefetching mobile ads can improve user experience, but it increases costs for advertising systems. We investigate whether advertising systems can afford prefetching. We analyze the trade-offs between prefetching benefits and costs, and propose cost-effective prefetching strategies. Our evaluation shows that selective prefetching can improve user experience while keeping costs manageable.

title: Whose cache line is it anyway?: operating system support for live detection and repair of false sharing.
abstract: False sharing causes performance degradation in multicore systems, but detecting and fixing it is challenging. We present operating system support for live detection and repair of false sharing. Our system monitors cache line access patterns and automatically repairs false sharing. We evaluate our approach and show that it can improve performance by detecting and fixing false sharing at runtime.

title: Augustus: scalable and robust storage for cloud applications.
abstract: Cloud applications need scalable and robust storage, but existing systems often sacrifice one for the other. We present Augustus, a scalable and robust storage system for cloud applications. Augustus uses novel replication and consistency mechanisms to provide both scalability and robustness. We evaluate Augustus and show that it can scale to large deployments while maintaining strong consistency guarantees.

title: Failure-atomic msync(): a simple and efficient mechanism for preserving the integrity of durable data.
abstract: Preserving data integrity across failures is critical, but existing mechanisms are complex. We present failure-atomic msync(), a simple and efficient mechanism for preserving the integrity of durable data. Our approach uses atomic write operations to ensure data integrity. We evaluate our approach and show that it can provide strong integrity guarantees with low overhead.

title: TimeStream: reliable stream computation in the cloud.
abstract: Reliable stream computation in the cloud is challenging due to failures and network issues. We present TimeStream, a reliable stream computation system for the cloud. TimeStream uses checkpointing and replication to ensure reliability. We evaluate TimeStream and show that it can provide reliable stream processing with low latency overhead.

title: Application level ballooning for efficient server consolidation.
abstract: Server consolidation can improve resource utilization, but existing ballooning mechanisms operate at the VM level. We present application-level ballooning for efficient server consolidation. Our approach allows applications to dynamically adjust their resource usage, enabling better consolidation. We evaluate our approach and show that it can improve consolidation efficiency.

title: IFDB: decentralized information flow control for databases.
abstract: Information flow control is important for database security, but existing systems are centralized. We present IFDB, a decentralized information flow control system for databases. IFDB allows multiple parties to enforce information flow policies without a central authority. We evaluate IFDB and show that it can provide strong security guarantees in decentralized settings.

title: Omega: flexible, scalable schedulers for large compute clusters.
abstract: Large compute clusters need flexible and scalable schedulers, but existing schedulers are monolithic. We present Omega, a flexible and scalable scheduler architecture for large compute clusters. Omega uses shared state and multiple schedulers to provide flexibility and scalability. We evaluate Omega and show that it can handle large-scale clusters efficiently.

title: Resolving the conflict between generality and plausibility in verified computation.
abstract: Verified computation systems face a conflict between generality and plausibility. General systems are complex and slow, while plausible systems are limited. We present techniques to resolve this conflict, enabling verified computation that is both general and plausible. We evaluate our approach and show that it can verify a wide range of computations efficiently.

title: Presto: distributed machine learning and graph processing with sparse matrices.
abstract: Distributed machine learning and graph processing often use sparse matrices, but existing systems don't optimize for sparsity. We present Presto, a system for distributed machine learning and graph processing with sparse matrices. Presto uses sparse matrix operations to improve performance. We evaluate Presto and show that it can efficiently handle large-scale sparse computations.

title: Process firewalls: protecting processes during resource access.
abstract: Processes need protection during resource access, but existing mechanisms are limited. We present process firewalls, a mechanism for protecting processes during resource access. Process firewalls use policy enforcement to control resource access. We evaluate process firewalls and show that they can provide effective protection with low overhead.

title: CPI2: CPU performance isolation for shared compute clusters.
abstract: Shared compute clusters need CPU performance isolation to prevent jobs from interfering with each other, but existing mechanisms are limited. We present CPI2, a CPU performance isolation system for shared compute clusters. CPI2 uses hardware counters and scheduling to provide performance isolation. We evaluate CPI2 and show that it can provide effective isolation with low overhead.

title: Maygh: building a CDN from client web browsers.
abstract: CDNs are expensive to deploy and maintain, but client web browsers can form a distributed CDN. We present Maygh, a system for building a CDN from client web browsers. Maygh uses browser-based caching and peer-to-peer distribution to deliver content. We evaluate Maygh and show that it can provide effective content delivery using client resources.

title: Ninth Eurosys Conference 2014, EuroSys 2014, Amsterdam, The Netherlands, April 13-16, 2014
abstract: Ninth EuroSys Conference 2014, held in Amsterdam, The Netherlands, April 13-16, 2014. EuroSys is a premier conference for systems research in Europe.

title: StackTrack: an automated transactional approach to concurrent memory reclamation.
abstract: Concurrent memory reclamation is challenging because it requires coordination between threads, but existing approaches are complex. We present StackTrack, an automated transactional approach to concurrent memory reclamation. StackTrack uses transactional memory to simplify memory reclamation. We evaluate StackTrack and show that it can provide safe memory reclamation with low overhead.

title: TESLA: temporally enhanced system logic assertions.
abstract: System logic assertions help verify system correctness, but existing assertions don't capture temporal properties. We present TESLA, temporally enhanced system logic assertions. TESLA extends system logic with temporal operators to express time-dependent properties. We evaluate TESLA and show that it can express and verify complex temporal properties in operating systems.

title: Archiving cold data in warehouses with clustered network coding.
abstract: Archiving cold data in warehouses is expensive, but network coding can reduce storage costs. We present a clustered network coding approach for archiving cold data in warehouses. Our approach uses network coding to reduce storage requirements while maintaining reliability. We evaluate our approach and show that it can significantly reduce storage costs for cold data.

title: TAQ: enhancing fairness and performance predictability in small packet regimes.
abstract: Small packet regimes pose challenges for fairness and performance predictability, but existing schedulers don't handle them well. We present TAQ, a scheduler that enhances fairness and performance predictability in small packet regimes. TAQ uses novel scheduling algorithms to provide fair and predictable performance. We evaluate TAQ and show that it can improve fairness and predictability for small packets.

title: Kronos: the design and implementation of an event ordering service.
abstract: Event ordering is fundamental for distributed systems, but existing services are complex. We present Kronos, an event ordering service that provides global ordering with low overhead. Kronos uses logical clocks and efficient algorithms to order events. We evaluate Kronos and show that it can provide efficient event ordering for large-scale distributed systems.

title: Relational access to Unix kernel data structures.

authors.name: Marios Fragkoulis
affiliations: Athens University of Economics and Business

authors.name: Diomidis Spinellis
affiliations: Athens University of Economics and Business

authors.name: Panos Louridas
affiliations: Athens University of Economics and Business

abstract: Accessing Unix kernel data structures is challenging because they are not exposed in a structured way. We present a system for relational access to Unix kernel data structures. Our system exposes kernel data as relational tables, enabling SQL queries. We evaluate our system and show that it can simplify kernel analysis and debugging.

title: Rex: replication at the speed of multi-core.
abstract: Replication is essential for fault tolerance, but existing replication systems don't fully utilize multi-core processors. We present Rex, a replication system that operates at the speed of multi-core. Rex uses parallel processing and efficient algorithms to achieve high throughput. We evaluate Rex and show that it can achieve near-linear scaling with core count.

title: Chronos: a graph engine for temporal graph analysis.

authors.name: Enhong Chen
affiliations: University of Science and Technology of China

abstract: Temporal graphs capture time-varying relationships, but existing graph engines don't handle temporal properties well. We present Chronos, a graph engine for temporal graph analysis. Chronos uses time-aware data structures and algorithms to efficiently process temporal graphs. We evaluate Chronos and show that it can efficiently analyze large-scale temporal graphs.

title: Callisto: co-scheduling parallel runtime systems.
abstract: Parallel runtime systems need efficient scheduling, but existing schedulers don't coordinate well. We present Callisto, a co-scheduling system for parallel runtime systems. Callisto coordinates scheduling across multiple runtime systems to improve performance. We evaluate Callisto and show that it can improve performance by coordinating parallel runtime systems.

title: Efficiently, effectively detecting mobile app bugs with AppDoctor.
abstract: Detecting bugs in mobile apps is challenging due to the complexity of mobile environments. We present AppDoctor, a system for efficiently and effectively detecting mobile app bugs. AppDoctor uses static and dynamic analysis to find bugs. We evaluate AppDoctor and show that it can find bugs efficiently with high accuracy.

title: An aggressive worn-out flash block management scheme to alleviate SSD performance degradation.

authors.name: Ping Huang
affiliations: Huazhong University of Science and Technology

authors.name: Weijun Xiao
affiliations: Huazhong University of Science and Technology

abstract: SSD performance degrades as flash blocks wear out, but existing management schemes are conservative. We present an aggressive worn-out flash block management scheme to alleviate SSD performance degradation. Our scheme uses aggressive wear leveling and block management to maintain performance. We evaluate our scheme and show that it can reduce performance degradation significantly.

title: Practical techniques to obviate setuid-to-root binaries.
abstract: Setuid-to-root binaries are a security risk, but they are widely used. We present practical techniques to obviate setuid-to-root binaries. Our techniques use capability-based access control and privilege separation to eliminate the need for setuid. We evaluate our techniques and show that they can replace setuid binaries while maintaining functionality.

title: T-Rex: a dynamic race detection tool for C/C++ transactional memory applications.
abstract: Detecting races in transactional memory applications is challenging because transactions hide races. We present T-Rex, a dynamic race detection tool for C/C++ transactional memory applications. T-Rex uses novel techniques to detect races in transactional code. We evaluate T-Rex and show that it can effectively detect races with low overhead.

title: TrustLite: a security architecture for tiny embedded devices.
abstract: Tiny embedded devices need security, but existing security architectures are too heavy. We present TrustLite, a security architecture for tiny embedded devices. TrustLite uses lightweight trusted computing primitives to provide security. We evaluate TrustLite and show that it can provide strong security guarantees with minimal overhead.

title: Reconciling high server utilization and sub-millisecond quality-of-service.
abstract: High server utilization and sub-millisecond QoS are conflicting goals, but both are important. We present techniques to reconcile high server utilization and sub-millisecond quality-of-service. Our techniques use resource isolation and scheduling to achieve both goals. We evaluate our techniques and show that they can achieve high utilization while maintaining sub-millisecond latency.

title: Algorithmic improvements for fast concurrent Cuckoo hashing.
abstract: Concurrent Cuckoo hashing is challenging because it requires coordination between threads, but existing implementations are slow. We present algorithmic improvements for fast concurrent Cuckoo hashing. Our improvements use lock-free techniques and better algorithms to improve performance. We evaluate our improvements and show that they can significantly improve concurrent Cuckoo hashing performance.

title: Caching in video CDNs: building strong lines of defense.
abstract: Video CDNs need effective caching to handle large traffic volumes, but existing caching strategies are limited. We present techniques for building strong lines of defense in video CDN caching. Our techniques use multi-level caching and intelligent placement to improve performance. We evaluate our techniques and show that they can significantly improve cache hit rates and reduce latency.

title: System software for persistent memory.
abstract: Persistent memory requires new system software to fully utilize its capabilities, but existing systems are designed for traditional storage. We present system software for persistent memory that provides efficient access and durability guarantees. Our software uses memory-mapped interfaces and atomic operations to provide high performance. We evaluate our system software and show that it can significantly improve performance for persistent memory applications.

title: From application requests to virtual IOPs: provisioned key-value storage with Libra.
abstract: Provisioned key-value storage needs to translate application requests to virtual IOPs, but existing systems don't provide good provisioning guarantees. We present Libra, a provisioned key-value storage system that maps application requests to virtual IOPs. Libra uses admission control and scheduling to provide provisioning guarantees. We evaluate Libra and show that it can provide predictable performance for key-value workloads.

title: Snapshots in a flash with ioSnap.
abstract: Creating snapshots on flash storage is challenging because flash has different characteristics than traditional storage. We present ioSnap, a system for creating snapshots in a flash with low overhead. ioSnap uses copy-on-write and efficient data structures to create snapshots quickly. We evaluate ioSnap and show that it can create snapshots with minimal performance impact.

title: DynMR: dynamic MapReduce with ReduceTask interleaving and MapTask backfilling.
abstract: MapReduce jobs can benefit from dynamic scheduling, but existing systems use static scheduling. We present DynMR, a dynamic MapReduce system with ReduceTask interleaving and MapTask backfilling. DynMR uses dynamic scheduling to improve resource utilization and job completion time. We evaluate DynMR and show that it can significantly improve MapReduce performance.

title: Cooperation and security isolation of library OSes for multi-process applications.
abstract: Library OSes need to support multi-process applications while maintaining security isolation, but existing systems don't balance cooperation and isolation well. We present techniques for cooperation and security isolation of library OSes for multi-process applications. Our techniques use shared memory and isolation mechanisms to enable cooperation while maintaining security. We evaluate our techniques and show that they can support multi-process applications efficiently.

title: Aerie: flexible file-system interfaces to storage-class memory.
abstract: Storage-class memory requires flexible file-system interfaces to fully utilize its capabilities, but existing interfaces are designed for traditional storage. We present Aerie, flexible file-system interfaces to storage-class memory. Aerie provides both traditional and memory-mapped interfaces to enable different access patterns. We evaluate Aerie and show that it can provide efficient access to storage-class memory.

title: Using restricted transactional memory to build a scalable in-memory database.
abstract: In-memory databases need scalable concurrency control, but existing mechanisms don't scale well. We present a scalable in-memory database built using restricted transactional memory. Our database uses hardware transactional memory to provide efficient concurrency control. We evaluate our database and show that it can scale to many cores while maintaining high performance.

title: An efficient design and implementation of LSM-tree based key-value store on open-channel SSD.
abstract: LSM-tree based key-value stores can benefit from open-channel SSDs, but existing designs don't fully utilize SSD characteristics. We present an efficient design and implementation of LSM-tree based key-value store on open-channel SSD. Our design uses direct access to flash channels to improve performance. We evaluate our design and show that it can significantly improve key-value store performance.

title: DIBS: just-in-time congestion mitigation for data centers.
abstract: Data center networks need just-in-time congestion mitigation to handle traffic bursts, but existing systems react too slowly. We present DIBS, a just-in-time congestion mitigation system for data centers. DIBS uses fast detection and mitigation to handle congestion quickly. We evaluate DIBS and show that it can effectively mitigate congestion with low latency.

title: WCMP: weighted cost multipathing for improved fairness in data centers.
abstract: Data center networks need fair multipathing to balance load, but existing multipathing schemes don't provide good fairness. We present WCMP, weighted cost multipathing for improved fairness in data centers. WCMP uses weighted path selection to improve fairness. We evaluate WCMP and show that it can significantly improve fairness while maintaining performance.

title: Putting consistency back into eventual consistency.
abstract: Eventual consistency systems often lack strong consistency guarantees, but applications need consistency. We present techniques for putting consistency back into eventual consistency. Our techniques use conflict-free replicated data types and consistency protocols to provide stronger guarantees. We evaluate our techniques and show that they can provide better consistency while maintaining availability.

title: Popcorn: bridging the programmability gap in heterogeneous-ISA platforms.
abstract: Heterogeneous-ISA platforms offer performance benefits, but programming them is challenging due to ISA differences. We present Popcorn, a system for bridging the programmability gap in heterogeneous-ISA platforms. Popcorn uses unified compilation and runtime support to enable seamless execution across ISAs. We evaluate Popcorn and show that it can simplify programming while maintaining performance.

title: PowerLyra: differentiated graph computation and partitioning on skewed graphs.
abstract: Skewed graphs pose challenges for graph computation and partitioning, but existing systems don't handle skew well. We present PowerLyra, a system for differentiated graph computation and partitioning on skewed graphs. PowerLyra uses hybrid partitioning and computation strategies to handle skew. We evaluate PowerLyra and show that it can significantly improve performance on skewed graphs.

title: An in-memory object caching framework with adaptive load balancing.
abstract: In-memory object caching needs adaptive load balancing to handle dynamic workloads, but existing systems use static balancing. We present an in-memory object caching framework with adaptive load balancing. Our framework uses dynamic rebalancing to adapt to workload changes. We evaluate our framework and show that it can maintain balanced load while providing high performance.

title: CYRUS: towards client-defined cloud storage.
abstract: Cloud storage systems are provider-defined, but clients have diverse requirements. We present CYRUS, a system towards client-defined cloud storage. CYRUS allows clients to specify storage policies and requirements. We evaluate CYRUS and show that it can provide better storage services tailored to client needs.

title: Process-level power estimation in VM-based systems.
abstract: Process-level power estimation in VM-based systems is challenging because VMs abstract hardware, but accurate estimation is needed for energy management. We present techniques for process-level power estimation in VM-based systems. Our techniques use hardware counters and VM-level monitoring to estimate power. We evaluate our techniques and show that they can provide accurate power estimates.

title: Extensible distributed coordination.
abstract: Distributed coordination systems need extensibility to support diverse applications, but existing systems are monolithic. We present an extensible distributed coordination system that allows customization of coordination protocols. Our system uses a plugin architecture to enable extensibility. We evaluate our system and show that it can support diverse coordination requirements efficiently.

title: Musketeer: all for one, one for all in data processing systems.

authors.name: Natacha Crooks
affiliations: Max Planck Institute for Software Systems

authors.name: Allen Clement
affiliations: Max Planck Institute for Software Systems

abstract: Data processing systems are fragmented, but unified systems can improve efficiency. We present Musketeer, a unified data processing system that supports multiple frameworks. Musketeer uses a common execution engine to enable resource sharing and optimization. We evaluate Musketeer and show that it can improve resource utilization and performance across different workloads.

title: Scaling concurrent log-structured data stores.
abstract: Concurrent log-structured data stores need to scale, but existing designs don't scale well with concurrency. We present techniques for scaling concurrent log-structured data stores. Our techniques use lock-free algorithms and efficient data structures to improve scalability. We evaluate our techniques and show that they can significantly improve concurrent performance.

title: Hare: a file system for non-cache-coherent multicores.
abstract: Non-cache-coherent multicores require new file system designs, but existing file systems assume cache coherence. We present Hare, a file system for non-cache-coherent multicores. Hare uses explicit synchronization and message passing to provide consistency. We evaluate Hare and show that it can provide efficient file system operations on non-cache-coherent multicores.

title: Flux: multi-surface computing in Android.
abstract: Multi-surface computing enables applications to span multiple devices, but Android doesn't support it natively. We present Flux, a system for multi-surface computing in Android. Flux provides APIs and runtime support for multi-surface applications. We evaluate Flux and show that it can enable seamless multi-surface computing on Android devices.

title: Application-assisted live migration of virtual machines with Java applications.
abstract: Live migration of VMs with Java applications is challenging because Java has complex state, but application assistance can help. We present application-assisted live migration of virtual machines with Java applications. Our approach uses application-level checkpointing to reduce migration time. We evaluate our approach and show that it can significantly reduce migration downtime.

title: ConfValley: a systematic configuration validation framework for cloud services.
abstract: Configuration errors cause many cloud service failures, but validating configurations is challenging. We present ConfValley, a systematic configuration validation framework for cloud services. ConfValley uses model checking and testing to validate configurations. We evaluate ConfValley and show that it can detect configuration errors effectively.

title: Deriving and comparing deduplication techniques using a model-based classification.
abstract: Deduplication techniques vary widely, but comparing them is challenging. We present a model-based classification for deriving and comparing deduplication techniques. Our classification uses mathematical models to characterize techniques. We evaluate our classification and show that it can help select appropriate deduplication techniques.

title: NBA (network balancing act): a high-performance packet processing framework for heterogeneous processors.
abstract: Heterogeneous processors offer performance benefits for packet processing, but balancing load across processors is challenging. We present NBA, a high-performance packet processing framework for heterogeneous processors. NBA uses dynamic load balancing to distribute packets efficiently. We evaluate NBA and show that it can achieve high throughput on heterogeneous processors.

title: Taming uncertainty in distributed systems with help from the network.

authors.name: Trinabh Gupta
affiliations: The University of Texas at Austin and New York University

abstract: Uncertainty in distributed systems causes correctness problems, but network support can help. We present techniques for taming uncertainty in distributed systems with help from the network. Our techniques use network-level guarantees to reduce uncertainty. We evaluate our techniques and show that they can improve system correctness and performance.

title: GD-Wheel: a cost-aware replacement policy for key-value stores.
abstract: Key-value stores need cost-aware replacement policies to optimize performance, but existing policies don't consider costs. We present GD-Wheel, a cost-aware replacement policy for key-value stores. GD-Wheel uses cost models to make replacement decisions. We evaluate GD-Wheel and show that it can improve performance by considering access costs.

title: MALT: distributed data-parallelism for existing ML applications.
abstract: Existing ML applications need distributed data-parallelism to scale, but rewriting them is expensive. We present MALT, a system for distributed data-parallelism for existing ML applications. MALT uses automatic parallelization to enable distributed execution. We evaluate MALT and show that it can scale existing ML applications without code changes.

title: High-performance determinism with total store order consistency.
abstract: Deterministic execution is important for debugging, but existing deterministic systems have high overhead. We present techniques for high-performance determinism with total store order consistency. Our techniques use TSO to reduce overhead while maintaining determinism. We evaluate our techniques and show that they can provide deterministic execution with low overhead.

title: Verifiable differential privacy.
abstract: Differential privacy provides strong privacy guarantees, but verifying implementations is challenging. We present techniques for verifiable differential privacy. Our techniques use cryptographic proofs to verify privacy properties. We evaluate our techniques and show that they can provide verifiable privacy guarantees.

title: Simba: tunable end-to-end data consistency for mobile apps.
abstract: Mobile apps need tunable data consistency to balance performance and correctness, but existing systems don't provide good tunability. We present Simba, a system for tunable end-to-end data consistency for mobile apps. Simba allows apps to choose consistency levels based on their needs. We evaluate Simba and show that it can improve performance while maintaining correctness.

title: Visigoth fault tolerance.
abstract: Byzantine fault tolerance is important for distributed systems, but existing systems have high overhead. We present Visigoth, a Byzantine fault-tolerant system with low overhead. Visigoth uses efficient protocols to provide fault tolerance. We evaluate Visigoth and show that it can provide strong fault tolerance with acceptable overhead.

title: SpotCheck: designing a derivative IaaS cloud on the spot market.
abstract: Spot markets offer low-cost cloud resources, but building IaaS on spot markets is challenging. We present SpotCheck, a derivative IaaS cloud on the spot market. SpotCheck uses spot instances and checkpointing to provide reliable IaaS. We evaluate SpotCheck and show that it can provide cost-effective IaaS with acceptable availability.

title: In-Net: in-network processing for the masses.
abstract: In-network processing can improve performance, but programming network devices is challenging. We present In-Net, a system for in-network processing for the masses. In-Net provides high-level abstractions for network programming. We evaluate In-Net and show that it can enable efficient in-network processing.

title: Guardat: enforcing data policies at the storage layer.
abstract: Data policies need to be enforced at the storage layer to prevent unauthorized access, but existing systems enforce policies at higher layers. We present Guardat, a system for enforcing data policies at the storage layer. Guardat uses storage-level mechanisms to enforce policies. We evaluate Guardat and show that it can provide strong policy enforcement.

title: Large-scale cluster management at Google with Borg.
abstract: Google operates large-scale clusters that require efficient management. We present Borg, Google's cluster management system. Borg handles scheduling, resource allocation, and fault tolerance for millions of jobs. We describe Borg's design and show how it manages Google's production workloads efficiently.

title: Synapse: a microservices architecture for heterogeneous-database web applications.
abstract: Heterogeneous-database web applications need microservices architectures, but existing systems don't handle database heterogeneity well. We present Synapse, a microservices architecture for heterogeneous-database web applications. Synapse provides abstractions for managing multiple database types. We evaluate Synapse and show that it can simplify application development.

title: TinMan: eliminating confidential mobile data exposure with security oriented offloading.
abstract: Mobile computation offloading can expose confidential data, but security-oriented offloading can prevent exposure. We present TinMan, a system for eliminating confidential mobile data exposure with security-oriented offloading. TinMan uses secure offloading mechanisms to protect data. We evaluate TinMan and show that it can prevent data exposure while enabling offloading.

title: Maxoid: transparently confining mobile applications with custom views of state.

authors.name: Emmett Witchel
affiliations: The University of Texas at Austin

abstract: Mobile applications need confinement to prevent unauthorized access, but existing confinement mechanisms are intrusive. We present Maxoid, a system for transparently confining mobile applications with custom views of state. Maxoid uses state views to provide isolation. We evaluate Maxoid and show that it can provide effective confinement with low overhead.

title: μPnP: plug and play peripherals for the internet of things.
abstract: IoT devices need plug-and-play peripherals to simplify deployment, but existing systems don't support it well. We present μPnP, a plug-and-play system for IoT peripherals. μPnP provides automatic device discovery and configuration. We evaluate μPnP and show that it can simplify IoT device management.

title: Guaranteeing deadlines for inter-datacenter transfers.

authors.name: Kai Chen
affiliations: Hong Kong University of Science and Technology

authors.name: Wei Bai
affiliations: Hong Kong University of Science & Technology

authors.name: Hao Wang
affiliations: Hong Kong University of Science & Technology and Shanghai Jiao Tong University

abstract: Inter-datacenter transfers need deadline guarantees, but existing systems don't provide them. We present techniques for guaranteeing deadlines for inter-datacenter transfers. Our techniques use deadline-aware scheduling and bandwidth allocation. We evaluate our techniques and show that they can guarantee deadlines while maintaining high utilization.

title: An efficient page-level FTL to optimize address translation in flash memory.

authors.name: You Zhou
affiliations: Huazhong University of Science and Technology

authors.name: Fei Wu
affiliations: Huazhong University of Science and Technology

authors.name: Ping Huang
affiliations: Huazhong University of Science and Technology

authors.name: Changsheng Xie
affiliations: Huazhong University of Science and Technology

authors.name: Jian Zhou
affiliations: Huazhong University of Science and Technology

abstract: Flash memory needs efficient FTL for address translation, but existing FTLs have high overhead. We present an efficient page-level FTL to optimize address translation in flash memory. Our FTL uses page-level mapping to reduce overhead. We evaluate our FTL and show that it can improve performance significantly.

title: POSIX abstractions in modern operating systems: the old, the new, and the missing.
abstract: POSIX abstractions are fundamental to operating systems, but their implementation varies across systems. We analyze POSIX abstractions in modern operating systems, identifying what's old, new, and missing. Our analysis reveals gaps and inconsistencies in POSIX support. We provide recommendations for improving POSIX compatibility.

title: On the capacity of thermal covert channels in multicores.
abstract: Thermal covert channels can leak information in multicores, but their capacity is unknown. We analyze the capacity of thermal covert channels in multicores. Our analysis shows that thermal channels can achieve significant bandwidth. We evaluate mitigation strategies and show their effectiveness.

title: Sinter: low-bandwidth remote access for the visually-impaired.
abstract: Visually-impaired users need low-bandwidth remote access, but existing systems don't optimize for accessibility. We present Sinter, a low-bandwidth remote access system for the visually-impaired. Sinter uses efficient encoding and screen reader integration to reduce bandwidth. We evaluate Sinter and show that it can provide effective remote access with low bandwidth.

title: Fast and general distributed transactions using RDMA and HTM.
abstract: Distributed transactions need high performance, but existing systems don't fully utilize RDMA and HTM. We present techniques for fast and general distributed transactions using RDMA and HTM. Our techniques combine RDMA and HTM to improve performance. We evaluate our techniques and show that they can significantly improve transaction throughput.

title: vScale: automatic and efficient processor scaling for SMP virtual machines.
abstract: SMP virtual machines need automatic processor scaling to adapt to workload changes, but existing systems don't scale efficiently. We present vScale, a system for automatic and efficient processor scaling for SMP virtual machines. vScale uses workload analysis to scale processors dynamically. We evaluate vScale and show that it can improve resource utilization and performance.

title: GeePS: scalable deep learning on distributed GPUs with a GPU-specialized parameter server.
abstract: Distributed deep learning needs scalable parameter servers, but existing servers don't fully utilize GPUs. We present GeePS, a GPU-specialized parameter server for scalable deep learning on distributed GPUs. GeePS uses GPU-optimized data structures and algorithms to improve performance. We evaluate GeePS and show that it can scale to many GPUs efficiently.

title: Shared address translation revisited.
abstract: Shared address translation can improve performance in virtualized environments, but existing approaches have limitations. We revisit shared address translation and present improved techniques. Our techniques use better data structures and algorithms to improve performance. We evaluate our techniques and show that they can significantly improve address translation performance.

title: Data tiering in heterogeneous memory systems.
abstract: Heterogeneous memory systems need data tiering to optimize performance, but existing systems don't tier efficiently. We present techniques for data tiering in heterogeneous memory systems. Our techniques use access patterns to place data optimally. We evaluate our techniques and show that they can improve performance by placing data in appropriate memory tiers.

title: Hardware read-write lock elision.
abstract: Read-write lock elision can improve performance, but existing hardware support is limited. We present hardware read-write lock elision techniques. Our techniques use hardware transactional memory to elide locks. We evaluate our techniques and show that they can improve performance by reducing lock contention.

title: Yoda: a highly available layer-7 load balancer.
abstract: Layer-7 load balancers need high availability, but existing systems don't provide it well. We present Yoda, a highly available layer-7 load balancer. Yoda uses replication and failover mechanisms to provide high availability. We evaluate Yoda and show that it can provide reliable load balancing with low downtime.

title: Juggler: a practical reordering resilient network stack for datacenters.
abstract: Datacenter networks cause packet reordering, but existing network stacks don't handle it well. We present Juggler, a practical reordering resilient network stack for datacenters. Juggler uses reordering-aware algorithms to handle out-of-order packets. We evaluate Juggler and show that it can improve performance in reordering-prone environments.

title: Type-aware transactions for faster concurrent code.
abstract: Transactional memory can simplify concurrent code, but type-aware transactions can improve performance. We present type-aware transactions for faster concurrent code. Our transactions use type information to optimize execution. We evaluate our approach and show that it can improve performance while maintaining correctness.

title: NChecker: saving mobile app developers from network disruptions.
abstract: Network disruptions cause mobile app failures, but detecting and handling them is challenging. We present NChecker, a system for saving mobile app developers from network disruptions. NChecker detects network issues and provides debugging support. We evaluate NChecker and show that it can help developers handle network disruptions effectively.

title: pVM: persistent virtual memory for efficient capacity scaling and object storage.
abstract: pVM provides persistent virtual memory for efficient capacity scaling and object storage. It enables applications to use persistent memory as a unified storage and memory layer, improving performance and simplifying data management.

title: STRADS: a distributed framework for scheduled model parallel machine learning.
abstract: STRADS is a distributed framework for scheduled model parallel machine learning. It provides efficient scheduling and communication for large-scale machine learning workloads, enabling better performance and scalability.

title: Flash storage disaggregation.
abstract: We present flash storage disaggregation, a new architecture for data center storage. Our approach separates flash storage from compute, enabling better resource utilization and cost efficiency.

title: Hold 'em or fold 'em?: aggregation queries under performance variations.
abstract: We study aggregation queries under performance variations in distributed systems. We present techniques for handling performance variability and improving query reliability and performance.

title: HAFT: hardware-assisted fault tolerance.
abstract: HAFT provides hardware-assisted fault tolerance for modern systems. It uses hardware features to improve fault tolerance efficiency and reduce overhead, enabling better reliability for critical applications.

title: Exploiting variability for energy optimization of parallel programs.
abstract: We present techniques for exploiting variability for energy optimization of parallel programs. Our approach uses performance variability to optimize energy consumption while maintaining performance targets.

title: PSLO: enforcing the Xth percentile latency and throughput SLOs for consolidated VM storage.

authors.name: Ning Li
affiliations: Huazhong University of Science and Technology

authors.name: Hong Jiang
affiliations: Huazhong University of Science and Technology

authors.name: Dan Feng
affiliations: Huazhong University of Science and Technology

authors.name: Zhan Shi
affiliations: Huazhong University of Science and Technology

abstract: PSLO enforces the Xth percentile latency and throughput SLOs for consolidated VM storage. It provides guaranteed performance for virtualized storage systems, enabling better resource utilization.

title: BB: booting booster for consumer electronics with modern OS.
abstract: BB (Booting Booster) improves boot time for consumer electronics with modern OS. It uses various optimization techniques to reduce boot time and improve user experience.

title: The Linux scheduler: a decade of wasted cores.
abstract: We analyze the Linux scheduler over a decade and identify wasted cores. Our study reveals scheduling inefficiencies and proposes improvements for better multicore utilization.

title: Partial-parallel-repair (PPR): a distributed technique for repairing erasure coded storage.
abstract: PPR (Partial-Parallel-Repair) is a distributed technique for repairing erasure coded storage. It improves repair efficiency by using partial parallelism, reducing repair time and network traffic.

title: Optimizing distributed actor systems for dynamic interactive services.
