abstract: We present optimizations for distributed actor systems for dynamic interactive services. Our approach improves performance and resource utilization for interactive workloads with varying demands.

title: A high performance file system for non-volatile main memory.
abstract: We present a high performance file system for non-volatile main memory. Our design takes advantage of NVM characteristics to provide better performance and durability guarantees.

title: Efficient queue management for cluster scheduling.
abstract: We present efficient queue management for cluster scheduling. Our approach improves scheduling efficiency and reduces queue wait times for large-scale cluster workloads.

title: Flint: batch-interactive data-intensive processing on transient servers.
abstract: Flint enables batch-interactive data-intensive processing on transient servers. It provides efficient execution for data-intensive workloads using spot instances and transient resources.

title: Crayon: saving power through shape and color approximation on next-generation displays.
abstract: Crayon saves power through shape and color approximation on next-generation displays. It reduces display power consumption by approximating content while maintaining visual quality.

title: Application-specific quantum for multi-core platform scheduler.
abstract: We present application-specific quantum for multi-core platform scheduler. Our approach uses application characteristics to optimize scheduling quantum, improving performance and fairness.

title: A study of modern Linux API usage and compatibility: what to support when you're supporting.
abstract: We study modern Linux API usage and compatibility. Our analysis identifies which APIs to support and provides insights for system design and compatibility maintenance.

title: TetriSched: global rescheduling with adaptive plan-ahead in dynamic heterogeneous clusters.
abstract: TetriSched provides global rescheduling with adaptive plan-ahead in dynamic heterogeneous clusters. It improves cluster utilization and job performance through intelligent rescheduling.

title: Practical condition synchronization for transactional memory.
abstract: We present practical condition synchronization for transactional memory. Our approach enables efficient condition variable operations within transactions, improving concurrent programming support.

title: Parallel sections: scaling system-level data-structures.
abstract: We present parallel sections, a mechanism for scaling system-level data-structures. Our approach enables efficient parallel access to shared data structures, improving performance and scalability. We evaluate parallel sections and demonstrate significant improvements.

title: Increasing large-scale data center capacity by statistical power control.
abstract: We present statistical power control techniques for increasing large-scale data center capacity. Our approach uses statistical methods to optimize power allocation, enabling better capacity utilization while maintaining energy efficiency. We evaluate our techniques and show significant improvements in data center capacity.

title: zExpander: a key-value cache with both high performance and fewer misses.
abstract: zExpander is a key-value cache that achieves both high performance and fewer misses. It uses novel caching strategies to improve hit rates while maintaining low latency. We evaluate zExpander and demonstrate significant improvements over existing cache systems.

title: Picocenter: supporting long-lived, mostly-idle applications in cloud environments.
abstract: Picocenter supports long-lived, mostly-idle applications in cloud environments. It provides efficient resource management for applications with sporadic activity, reducing resource waste and costs. We evaluate Picocenter and show significant cost savings.

title: TFC: token flow control in data center networks.
abstract: TFC (Token Flow Control) provides efficient flow control in data center networks. It uses token-based mechanisms to manage network traffic, improving throughput and reducing congestion. We evaluate TFC and demonstrate better performance than existing approaches.

title: Oasis: energy proportionality with hybrid server consolidation.
abstract: Oasis achieves energy proportionality with hybrid server consolidation. It combines different consolidation strategies to optimize energy consumption while maintaining performance. We evaluate Oasis and show significant energy savings.

title: CloudTalk: Enabling Distributed Application Optimisations in Public Clouds.
abstract: CloudTalk enables distributed application optimisations in public clouds. It provides mechanisms for applications to optimize their execution across cloud resources, improving performance and reducing costs. We evaluate CloudTalk and demonstrate significant benefits.

title: SyncPerf: Categorizing, Detecting, and Diagnosing Synchronization Performance Bugs.

abstract: SyncPerf categorizes, detects, and diagnoses synchronization performance bugs. It provides comprehensive tools for identifying and fixing synchronization-related performance issues. We evaluate SyncPerf and show its effectiveness in finding real-world bugs.

title: Forkscan: Conservative Memory Reclamation for Modern Operating Systems.
abstract: Forkscan provides conservative memory reclamation for modern operating systems. It enables safe memory reclamation without requiring garbage collection, improving system performance. We evaluate Forkscan and demonstrate its effectiveness.

title: FloDB: Unlocking Memory in Persistent Key-Value Stores.
abstract: FloDB unlocks memory in persistent key-value stores. It provides efficient memory management for persistent storage systems, improving performance and reducing overhead. We evaluate FloDB and show significant improvements.

title: Hybrids on Steroids: SGX-Based High Performance BFT.
abstract: We present SGX-based high performance BFT (Byzantine Fault Tolerance). Our approach uses Intel SGX to improve BFT performance while maintaining security guarantees. We evaluate our system and demonstrate significant performance improvements.

title: A Characterization of State Spill in Modern Operating Systems.
abstract: We characterize state spill in modern operating systems. Our study reveals patterns in how operating systems manage state across different components, providing insights for system design and optimization.

title: Saturn: a Distributed Metadata Service for Causal Consistency.
abstract: Saturn is a distributed metadata service for causal consistency. It provides efficient metadata management for causally consistent systems, enabling better performance and scalability. We evaluate Saturn and demonstrate its effectiveness.

title: Abstracting Multi-Core Topologies with MCTOP.
abstract: MCTOP abstracts multi-core topologies for better parallel computing. It provides a unified abstraction for different multi-core architectures, simplifying parallel program development. We evaluate MCTOP and show its benefits.

title: One Primitive to Diagnose Them All: Architectural Support for Internet Diagnostics.
abstract: We present architectural support for Internet diagnostics. Our approach provides a primitive for diagnosing network issues, enabling better troubleshooting and debugging. We evaluate our design and demonstrate its effectiveness.

title: Online Reconstruction of Structural Information from Datacenter Logs.
abstract: We present online reconstruction of structural information from datacenter logs. Our approach extracts meaningful structures from log data, enabling better analysis and debugging. We evaluate our system and demonstrate its effectiveness.

title: Node.fz: Fuzzing the Server-Side Event-Driven Architecture.
abstract: Node.fz provides fuzzing for server-side event-driven architecture. It enables comprehensive testing of event-driven systems, finding bugs and vulnerabilities. We evaluate Node.fz and demonstrate its effectiveness.

title: Malthusian Locks.
abstract: We present Malthusian locks, a new locking mechanism for concurrent systems. Our approach addresses limitations of existing locks, providing better performance and scalability. We evaluate our design and demonstrate its benefits.

title: GfxDoctor: A Holistic Graphics Energy Profiler for Mobile Devices.
abstract: GfxDoctor is a holistic graphics energy profiler for mobile devices. It provides comprehensive energy profiling for graphics workloads, enabling better energy optimization. We evaluate GfxDoctor and demonstrate its effectiveness.

abstract: We present an empirical study on the correctness of formally verified distributed systems. Our study reveals insights into the effectiveness of formal verification and identifies areas for improvement.
